Steap 13 (Optional). By default, all traffic from the client is sent through the tunnel. You can configure split tunnel, which allows only selected traffic to go through the tunnel.

ip access-list standard split_tunnel
 permit 10.0.0.0 0.255.255.255
!
crypto ikev2 authorization policy ikev2-auth-policy 
 route set access-list split_tunnel
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/flexvpn/200555-FlexVPN-AnyConnect-IKEv2-Remote-Access.html#toc-hId-936641904

Answer should be A 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/flexvpn/200555-FlexVPN-AnyConnect-IKEv2-Remote-Access.html

n a Cisco router, split tunneling for IKEv2 remote access clients is typically defined within the Group Policy configuration. The Group Policy defines various parameters and settings for a particular group of remote access clients. Within the Group Policy configuration, you can specify whether split tunneling should be enabled or disabled for the IKEv2 remote access clients associated with that group. Split tunneling determines how network traffic is routed when a remote access client is connected to the router using IKEv2. It allows the client to decide which traffic should be sent through the VPN tunnel and which traffic should be directly routed to the local network or the internet. While IKEv2 Authorization Policy can also play a role in defining access permissions and policies for IKEv2 remote access clients, split tunneling itself is typically configured within the Group Policy. So, the correct answer is that split tunneling for IKEv2 remote access clients on a Cisco router is defined within the Group Policy.
A is the Correct answer
Group policy makes sense here.

questions.question_text: Where is split tunneling defined for IKEv2 remote access clients on a Cisco router?

discussion.content: When it comes to sending multicast traffic over a site-to-site VPN, the technology commonly used is GRE (Generic Routing Encapsulation) over IPsec. On IOS Router, you can configure GRE over IPsec to enable multicast traffic to traverse the VPN tunnel. It encapsulates multicast packets into GRE packets, which are then encrypted using IPsec. As for FTD (Firepower Threat Defense), it doesn't natively support GRE tunneling. However, you can still achieve multicast over IPsec functionality by using a workaround called IPsec Tunnel Mode over Transport Mode, which allows multicast traffic to pass through the IPsec tunnel. In summary, both IOS Router and FTD can handle multicast traffic over a site-to-site VPN, but the specific implementation may differ

Selected Answer: A
GRE is only supported on routers, making all other answers but A invalid

Selected Answer: A
agree with mazinhoo, Cisco link listed supports answer A

GRE is not supported in FTD, so A is correct

questions.question_text: Which technology is used to send multicast traffic over a site-to-site VPN?
Which feature of GETVPN is a limitation of DMVPN and FlexVPN?

choices.B: enabled use of ESP or AH
choices.C: design for use over public or private WAN
choices.A: sequence numbers that enable scalable replay checking
choices.D: no requirement for an overlay routing protocol

discussion.content:
Answer D is Correct.
one benefit of GET VPN is Simplified network design due to leveraging of native routing infrastructure (no overlay routing protocol needed)

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
